actions.text: Mr. Lewis of California reserved all points of order against consideration of the bill.
The House Committee on Appropriations reported an original measure, H. Rept. 101-648, by Mr. Fazio.
Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 404.

Rules Committee Resolution H. Res. 510 Reported to House. Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 5399. All points of order against consideration of the bill are waived. During consideration all points of order for failure to comply with clause 2 of rule XXI against certain provisions of the bill are waived. Measure will be read by section. Specified amendments are in order. It shall be in order to consider en bloc amendments numbered 1 printed in the Rules Committee report. Said amendments shall be debatable for 20 minutes, and are not subject to a demand for a division of the question and if adopted shall become original text. En bloc amendments numbered 2 in the report shall be debatable for 40 minutes, and are not subject to a demand for a division of the question. Amendment numbered 3 in the report shall be debatable for one hour. None of the amendments are subject to amendment.
Rule H. Res. 510 passed House.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 510.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 5399. All points of order against consideration of the bill are waived. During consideration all points of order for failure to comply with clause 2 of rule XXI against certain provisions of the bill are waived. Measure will be read by section. Specified amendments are in order. It shall be in order to consider en bloc amendments numbered 1 printed in the Rules Committee report. Said amendments shall be debatable for 20 minutes, and are not subject to a demand for a division of the question and if adopted shall become original text. En bloc amendments numbered 2 in the report shall be debatable for 40 minutes, and are not subject to a demand for a division of the question. Amendment numbered 3 in the report shall be debatable for one hour. None of the amendments are subject to amendment.
Mr. Fazio moved to resolve into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union.
Pending the foregoing motion, Mr. Fazio asked unanimous consent that the time for general debate be limited to one hour. Agreed to without objection.
On motion to resolve into Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union Agreed to without objection.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Dale E. Kildee to act as Chairman of the Committee.
GENERAL DEBATE - Pursuant to the previous unanimous consent agreement, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with one hour of general debate.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 510, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 20 minutes of debate on the amendment.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 510, the Committee of the whole proceeded with forty minutes of debate on the amendment.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 510, the Committee of the Whole House proceeded with one hour of debate on the Fazio amendment.
The House rose from the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union to report H.R. 5399.
The previous question was ordered without objection.
The House adopted the amendments en gros as agreed to by the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union.
On passage Passed by recorded vote: 292 - 117 (Roll no. 501).
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Received in the Senate, read twice.
Committted to Senate Committee on Appropriations with instructions to report back forthwith, incorporating the committee amendments as reflected in S. 3207 by Unanimous Consent.
Committee on Appropriations. Reported to Senate by Senator Reid with amendments. Without written report.
Measure laid before Senate by unanimous consent.
Amendment SP 3134 proposed by Senator Reid for Senator Ford.
Amendment SP 3134 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 3135 proposed by Senator Reid for Senator Ford.
Amendment SP 3135 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 3136 proposed by Senator Reid for Senator Ford.
Amendment SP 3136 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 3137 proposed by Senator Reid for Senator Ford.
Amendment SP 3138 proposed by Senator Reid.
Amendment SP 3137 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 3138 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 3139 proposed by Senator Reid for Senator Inouye.
Amendment SP 3139 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 3140 proposed by Senator Reid for Senator Nunn.
Amendment SP 3140 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 3141 proposed by Senator Reid for Senator Humphrey.
Amendment SP 3141 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 3142 proposed by Senator Reid.
Amendment SP 3142 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 3143 proposed by Senator Nickles.
Motion to table SP 3143 rejected in Senate by Yea-Nay Vote. 32-60. Record Vote No: 310.
Amendment SP 3143 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 3144 proposed by Senator Nickles.
Considered by Senate.
Amendment SP 3145 proposed by Senator Stevens to Amendment SP 3144.
Amendment SP 3145 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 3144 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 3146 proposed by Senator Nickles.
Amendment SP 3147 proposed by Senator Ford to Amendment SP 3146.
Amendment SP 3147 not agreed to in Senate by Yea-Nay Vote. 42-51. Record Vote No: 311.
Amendment SP 3146 agreed to in Senate by Yea-Nay Vote. 50-44. Record Vote No: 312.
Amendment SP 3159 proposed by Senator Reid.
Amendment SP 3159 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 3160 proposed by Senator Stevens.
Amendment SP 3160 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 3161 proposed by Senator Wirth.
Amendment SP 3162 proposed by Senator Reid for Senator Ford.
Amendment SP 3162 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 3161 agreed to in Senate by Yea-Nay Vote. 73-22. Record Vote No: 313.
Passed Senate with amendments by Yea-Nay Vote. 72-24. Record Vote No: 314.
Senate insists on its amendments, asks for a conference, appoints conferees Reid; Mikulski; Adams; Byrd; Nickles; Stevens; Cochran.
Mr. Fazio asked unanimous consent that the House disagree to the Senate amendments, and agree to a conference.
On motion that the House disagree to the Senate amendments, and agree to a conference Agreed to without objection.
The chair appointed conferees: Fazio, Yates, Obey, Murtha, Traxler, Boggs, Whitten, Lewis (CA), Conte, Myers, and Porter.
By unanimous consent, the Speaker reserved the authority to make additional appointments.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

Rules Committee Resolution H. Res. 540 Reported to House. Rule provides for consideration of the conference report to H.R. 5399. Upon adoption of this resolution it shall be in order to consider the conference report on the bill, and all points of order against the conference report and against its consideration shall be waived. The conference report shall be considered as having been read when called up for consideration.
Conference report H. Rept. 101-965 filed.
Mr. Fazio brought up conference report H.Rept. 101-965 for consideration under the provisions of H. Res. 540.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on the conference report.
The previous question was ordered without objection.
On agreeing to the conference report Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 259 - 129 (Roll no. 529).
Motions to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Cleared for White House.
Senate agreed to conference report by Voice Vote.
Conference papers: Senate report and managers' statement held at the desk in Senate.
Measure Signed in Senate.
Presented to President.
Signed by President.
Became Public Law No: 101-520.

official_title: Making appropriations for the Legislative Branch for the fiscal year ending September 30, 1991, and for other purposes.

summary.text: Legislative Branch Appropriations Act, 1991 - Title I: Congressional Operations - Congressional Operations Appropriations Act, 1991 - Appropriates funds for FY 1991 for the operations of the Senate and of the House of Representatives. Sets forth administrative provisions for the use of such funds. Appropriates funds for: (1) joint items of the House and Senate; (2) the Office of Technology Assessment; (3) the Congressional Budget Office; (4) the Office of the Architect of the Capitol; (5) the Congressional Research Service of the Library of Congress; and (6) congressional printing and binding at the Government Printing Office. Empowers U.S. Capitol Police to make arrests off Capitol grounds in certain circumstances. Title II: Other Agencies - Appropriates funds for: (1) the Botanic Garden; (2) the Library of Congress; (3) the Architect of the Capitol; (4) the Copyright Royalty Tribunal; (5) the Government Printing Office; and (6) the General Accounting Office. Sets forth limitations on the use of such funds. Authorizes appropriations for the Library to acquire specified property for: (1) a day care center for children of Library and other legislative branch employees; (2) staff development and training; and (3) other purposes relating to the Library's operations. Title III: General Provisions - Sets forth various specified requirements for and prohibitions or limitations on the use of appropriations. Directs the Architect of the Capitol to develop an overall telecommunications plan for the other agencies of the legislative branch that will be compatible with current plans of the House and the Senate. Authorizes legislative branch agencies to use telecommunications systems and services provided by the Architect of the Capitol, the House, or the Senate under a specified plan if such systems and services have been: (1) acquired competitively; and (2) determined to at least equal in quality to, and not greater in cost than, the systems and services known as "FTS2000." Amends Federal law to remove the disbursement authority of the Botanic Garden from the Library of Congress. Revises the authority for issuing the Speaker's Pay Orders. Requires Federal departments, agencies, or instrumentalities to have a policy designed to ensure that all of its workplaces are drug-free. Exempts Members of Congress and Senators from serving on State and local juries. Sets forth requirements and limitations on the use of the congressional frank. Establishes an Official Mail Allowance for Members, officers, and employees of the House of Representatives who are entitled to use the congressional frank. Withholds from obligation specified funds appropriated under this Act. Amends the John C. Stennis Center for Public Service Training and Development Act with respect to the Center's use of income from investments. Authorizes the President pro tempore of the Senate to adjust the pay to maintain the same pay relationships that existed on December 31, 1986, between personnel and Senators and between positions. Permits congressional mass mailings to countries adjoining a congressional district. Requires FY 1991 pay raises to be absorbed within the levels appropriated in this Act. Amends the United States Institute of Peace Act to authorize the U.S. Institute of Peace, through its Board of Directors, to award an annual Spark M. Matsunaga Medal of Peace and a cash award to a person or persons who have contributed in extraordinary ways to peace among the nations and peoples of the world, giving special attention to contributions advancing society's knowledge and skill in peacemaking and conflict management. Directs the Board to establish an advisory panel to advise in selection of award recipients. Requires the Institute to report to specified congressional committees on selection procedures. Requires quarterly registration of Senate mass mailings with the Secretary of the Senate. Provides for: (1) January 1991 cost-of-living adjustments for Federal judges; (2) certain reimbursements to the Library of Congress; (3) extension of funds available for specified Senate matters, including floor tracking cable TV channels; and (4) two cable TV stations for the House of Representatives.

titles.title: Making appropriations for the Legislative Branch for the fiscal year ending September 30, 1991, and for other purposes.
